results.title: Malaria: the recurring enemy
results.creator_credit: Department of Defence Public Relations and Vincent Donovan
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Sentinel”.
Malaria has again become a major world health problem. Strains of malaria parasite have been resistant to drugs and species of anopheles mosquito have developed a tolerance for insecticides. Although research is being carried out aimed at defeating the disease, it still poses a threat to some areas of Australia. Features some black and white sequences. Commentary by Roger Newcombe.

results.title: Malacca: then and now
results.brief_description: Shows Malacca, a small port in Malaya with a long history, including relics of the Hindus, Muslims, Portugese, Dutch and British. Provides glimpses of the religious traditions brought by these peoples, as well as the ancient funeral ceremonies of the Chinese. Claims that Malacca shows how Eastern and Western ways of life can settle down tolerantly together.

results.title: Making yourself understood: introduction to communication
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and John T. Bobbitt
results.brief_description: Language written or spoken, is our principle tool of communication. Essentials for communication - communicator, content, medium, audience, response. Knowing the type of audience being addressed is essential to getting your message across, and to getting the response you desire.

results.title: Making your presentation
results.brief_description: This program has been prepared specifically to help young people overcome their nerves and fears in speaking in public and, instead, make a presentation that is entertaining and rewarding. Students are introduced to some of the techniques used by professional presenters, including: planning and researching your topic; writing and timing your presentation; using confident body languauge, eye to eye contact and voice; using visual aids and handouts. Study guide included.

results.title: Making Window Pictures
results.brief_description: In the Brisbane Creative Leisure Centre, conducted by the Cantrills, children are shown reproductions of stained glass windows and then make large transparent pictures with black paper, coloured cellophane, and other materials such as discarded x-ray pictures and textured fabric, with a minimum of instruction. These are taken indoors and fastened to window panes.

results.title: Making waves = Te upoko o te ika
results.creator_credit: Nga Kara Whetu, TopShelf Productions, Carol J Paewai and Whetu Fala
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “From spirit to spirit (A)”.
The story of the Te Upoko o te ika, Maori radio station in Wellington, New Zealand. The station fights to survive in a world where ratings and market share are paramount. This program captures one day in the life of a radio station which aims to bring Maori traditions, language and culture to the modern world.

results.title: Making Venus
results.creator_credit: Australian Film Commission, Jotz Productions, SBS Independent, Tom Zubrycki and Gary Doust
results.brief_description: This Australian documentary about filmmaking stands as a testament to everything that can possibly go wrong in the process of producing and directing a feature film. Cousins Jason Gooden and Julian Saggers are exuberant, if inexperienced, producers of their first low-budget feature called “The Venus factory”; they’ve raised $100 000 and plan to seek a distributor once the film is completed. This work follows the cousins over the next four years, displaying everything that can and does go wrong with the production - a chaotic shoot; an evolving script; investors, including friends and family, pouring more money into the flailing production; escalating costs; two directors (Glenn Fraser and Denis Whitburn); three title changes; numerous re-edits, re-writes and re-shoots; uninterested distributors; and finally, a scathing audience reaction. One cannot help but admire the producers’ tenacity, who despite fielding nasty letters from investors and crew, persist with dogged determination to finish their debut work. Displays the perils of guerrilla filmmaking, whilst providing a fascinating and raw insight into the mixed fortunes of a difficult business. This is the cinema version, containing twenty minutes of extra footage from the television cut.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Australian Film Commission, Jotz Productions, SBS Independent, Tom Zubrycki and Gary Doust
